title: 103_s2016
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Commission on the Future of Disability Act". The Congress recognizes the need to ensure equality, full participation, independent living, and economic self-sufficiency for individuals with disabilities. The Federal Government has various programs to support their needs, but many operate inconsistently. Many Federal programs for individuals with disabilities are outdated, work against each other, or could be improved. There are also programs not specifically for disabilities that benefit many individuals with disabilities, but their impact is often overlooked. The nation lacks awareness of the growing number of Americans with disabilities, posing a health and social welfare challenge. It is crucial for the Federal Government to reassess its approach. The Federal Government needs to review its programs for individuals with disabilities to align with national goals, optimize resources, and adapt to societal and technological changes. The National Commission on the Future of Disability is established to review federal programs for individuals with disabilities and adapt to societal and technological changes. The Commission will conduct a comprehensive study of Federal programs for individuals with disabilities, focusing on current performance and future value. This includes analyzing trends in the disabled population, developing performance standards, and assessing rehabilitation research and training efforts. The Commission will assess Federal disability programs, recommend changes, and propose new legislation to improve program effectiveness and organization within the government. The Commission will evaluate Federal disability programs, suggest improvements, and propose new legislation to enhance program effectiveness and government organization. Additionally, the Commission will consider other actions to prevent disabilities and address related disadvantages, along with any other relevant matters. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by various political leaders based on their education, training, or experience. The Commission, consisting of 12 members appointed by political leaders, aims to reflect the diversity of individuals with disabilities in the US. The Comptroller General serves as an ex officio member to advise on the study. Appointed individuals cannot be government officers or employees and must be appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment, serving for the Commission's duration. The Commission, with 12 members appointed by political leaders, will be headquartered in DC and meet at least four times a year. Ten members form a quorum, with a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson chosen within 15 days of appointment. Members can continue if they join the government, and vacancies will be filled promptly. The Commission, with 12 members appointed by political leaders, will be headquartered in DC and meet at least four times a year. Ten members form a quorum, with a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson chosen within 15 days of appointment. Vacancies on the Commission must be filled within 30 days. Members receive no additional pay but are entitled to travel expenses as per regulations. SEC. 6. STAFF AND SUPPORT SERVICES. The Chairperson appoints a Director of the Commission who is paid at the rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint staff with Commission approval, without following certain Civil Service Laws. The Director can also procure temporary services with Commission approval. The Director can procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission has access to resources from the Library of Congress and other government branches. The General Services Administration will provide office space for the Commission. The Commission will have facilities serving as its headquarters with all necessary equipment for proper functioning. The Commission will have facilities serving as its headquarters with all necessary equipment for proper functioning. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission may conduct public hearings, delegate authority to its members or agents, obtain information from Federal agencies, and accept gifts or property. The Commission may accept gifts, bequests, or devices of services or property to aid its work. Money and proceeds from sales received shall be deposited in the Treasury for disbursement. The Commission can also use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. SEC. 8. REPORTS. The Commission is required to submit an interim report to the President and Congress one year before its termination, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations. A final report with detailed findings, conclusions, recommendations, and an assessment of implementation is due upon termination. Reports are to be printed and publicly distributed upon receipt. Upon receipt of each report from the Commission, the President will order it to be printed and available to the public upon request. The Commission will terminate 2 years after designating a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. Sums necessary for this Act are authorized to be appropriated.
